Re ''Before Memoirs, He Wrote A's, B's, C's, D's and F's'' (news article, Nov. 16):
Frank McCourt's stories about his life made him an unforgettable teacher. Now he has written about them in his new memoir, ''Teacher Man.''

Growing up as the daughter of uneducated Eastern European immigrants, I was no stranger to hopelessness, poverty and shame. While at Stuyvesant High School in New York City (class of 1983), I learned from Mr. McCourt that every life story is worth telling long before I learned from feminism that the personal is political.
I later aspired to become a teacher because of Mr. McCourt's unorthodox pedagogical style, and I remain one today because of his books.

I first heard about ''Angela's Ashes'' in a hospital bed while recovering from cancer. Since then, I have taught many college students how to write and perform personal narratives. I cannot think of better ways to learn self-affirmation.
I owe a great deal both personally and professionally to my former teacher, Mr. Frank McCourt.
